Establishing connections in the forgery market requires a careful balance of discretion, trust, and anonymity. The first step is to build a reputation through small, high-quality forgeries that circulate in obscure or underground channels. Word of mouth is essential—once a few pieces are successfully passed off as authentic, a name begins to develop in certain circles. 

I operate under multiple aliases and use intermediaries to maintain distance from the final product. It's important to avoid direct links to the art itself. Instead, I work with trusted individuals who handle the logistics—transport, delivery, and even the sale in some cases. These people are vetted thoroughly, often through mutual connections or by observing their reliability over time.

The market is rife with informants and law enforcement surveillance, so I avoid any digital footprint. All communication is done in person or through secure, analog methods—coded messages, handwritten notes, or face-to-face meetings in public places that allow for easy escape if necessary.

I also cultivate relationships with art restorers, framers, and even gallery owners who might be open to turning a blind eye in exchange for financial or professional favors. These individuals can be valuable assets in making a forgery appear legitimate from the moment it leaves my hands.

In high-stakes cases, I may collaborate with experts in materials science to ensure the age and composition of the materials used in the forgery match those of the period being replicated. This level of detail is crucial in deceiving even the most seasoned experts.

Ultimately, the key to navigating the risks is to never be greedy. I take calculated risks and move on before the work becomes too high-profile. The moment a forgery becomes too famous, it becomes too dangerous.
